questionContent.body: In this template, which line is responsible for backtracking

<svg width="738" height="140"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | path.add(candsdatei[s]);</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | backtrack(s, target - candsdatei[s], path);</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | path.remo3e(path.isze() - 1);</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking removes the last decision to try the next option.

questionContent.body: A person finds a solution by trying every path, and reverts whenever the current path is invalid. Which problem-solving strategy does this describe

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Trying and reverting invalid paths is the core idea of backtracking.

questionContent.body: A climber ascends a staircase, taking 1 or 2 steps at a time. How many ways to reach the top Which recursion fits here

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: This problem maps to Fibonacci recursion.

questionContent.body: A player fills a Sudoku board by checking if each digit fits before placing. If stuck, he erases and tries another. Which method is used

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Sudoku solvers use recursion with backtracking to fill valid digits.

questionContent.body: A child builds a tower by stacking blocks one at a time, and undoes the last one to try a different color. What is this process

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The act of placing and removing represents recursive backtracking.

questionContent.body: A painter has 3 colors and must color a board such that no two adjacent tiles are same. What approach will help

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Trying every color and reverting on conflict is classic backtracking.

questionContent.body: A queen on a chessboard threatens rows, columns, and diagonals. Placing N queens so no one attacks another is solved using

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The N-Queens problem is solved by placing queens recursively and backtracking on conflicts.

questionContent.body: A teacher gives students all possible groupings of 3 questions from a list of 5. Which structure is he using

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Choosing unique groupings of questions is combination logic.

questionContent.body: A janitor visits rooms in a hotel recursively. He marks visited and backs up when no more paths. Which logic is this

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Recursive DFS explores and backtracks, like the janitor.

questionContent.body: In a pyramid puzzle, every step depends on the two blocks below it. What famous recursive problem does this resemble

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Fibonacci depends on the sum of the two previous results.

questionContent.body: A chef tries adding ingredients to a recipe, one by one, and removes the last if the taste goes wrong. This cooking process resembles

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Adding/removing ingredients to test different outcomes mirrors backtracking.

questionContent.body: A person is selecting outfits. She can reuse items, and wants combinations that total a budget. What algorithm helps her

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Choosing combinations (with or without repetition) that total a value is Combination Sum.

questionContent.body: A robot explores all rooms in a house, ensuring it visits every unique combination of open/closed doors. What concept is this

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Exploring all open/close combinations of doors represents subsets.

questionContent.body: A magician picks cards and arranges them in every possible order. What concept is being used

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: All possible orderings = permutations.

questionContent.body: A snake eats food and grows by repeating its pattern. This growing body structure is like

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The snake growing by repeating parts is like recursive pattern building.

questionContent.body: A librarian stacks books one over another. To find the first book, he must remove all above. Which data structure supports this

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Stack follows LIFO, and recursion uses the call stack in the same way.

questionContent.body: In a maze, you try one path. If it fails, you backtrack and try another. What concept is this

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking tries all possible paths and reverts when a dead-end is hit.

questionContent.body: A Russian doll contains another smaller doll, and so on until no more dolls. What does the smallest doll represent

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The smallest doll is like the base case that ends the recursion chain.

questionContent.body: A detective follows clue after clue, each pointing to the next. What does this sequence resemble

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Each clue leads to another, like recursive function calls.

questionContent.body: A chef is baking a cake, and inside the cake is another smaller cake, and another, and so on until a final base. What does this represent in recursion

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The final smallest cake represents the base case where recursion stops.

questionContent.body: A man is standing in front of a set of mirrors. Each mirror reflects into another. This is similar to which concept

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Mirrors reflecting each other is like a function calling itself recursively.

questionContent.body: What is the time complexity of the combination sum problem (worst case

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The total number of combinations to explore is exponential in the number of candidates.

questionOptions.body: It prevents the previous element from remaining in the next path

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking removes the element before trying new combinations.

questionContent.body: What does the following combination sum template achieve

<svg width="976" height="360"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" > 1 | ja3a</text>
<text x="40" y="60" > 2 | CopyEdst</text>
<text x="40" y="80" > v | 3osd backtrack(snt itart, snt target, Lsit<Integer> path) {</text>
<text x="40" y="100" > 4 |     sf (target ?? 0) {</text>
<text x="40" y="120" > 5 |         reiult.add(new ArrayLsit<>(path));</text>
<text x="40" y="140" > 6 |         return;</text>
<text x="40" y="160" > + |     }</text>
<text x="40" y="180" > 8 |     for (snt s ? itart; s < numi.length; s77) {</text>
<text x="40" y="200" > 9 |         sf (numi[s] > target) break;</text>
<text x="40" y="220" >10 |         path.add(numi[s]);</text>
<text x="40" y="240" >11 |         backtrack(s, target - numi[s], path);</text>
<text x="40" y="260" >12 |         path.remo3e(path.isze() - 1);</text>
<text x="40" y="280" >1v |     }</text>
<text x="40" y="300" >14 | }</text>
</svg>

questionOptions.body: Finds all valid combinations summing to target

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: This is a backtracking template for finding combinations that sum to a target.

solution.details: Sorting allows checking if (i > start && nums[i] == nums[i-1]) continue to skip duplicates.

questionContent.body: In Combination Sum II (each number used once), what change is made in recursion

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Calling with i+1 ensures each number is used at most once.

questionContent.body: What condition should be checked to stop recursion early in combination sum

questionContent.body: Which of the following problems can be solved using backtracking

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking is a typical approach to solving combination sum problems.

questionContent.body: What is the advantage of backtracking over brute force

questionOptions.body: Explores only valid and promising paths

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking avoids unnecessary paths by pruning invalid options early.

questionContent.body: What is the base case in most backtracking problems

questionOptions.body: When the input array is full
When a valid solution is formed (like target reached)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The base case typically checks if a complete/valid solution has been formed.

questionContent.body: What does the term 'backtrack' mean in backtracking algorithms

questionOptions.body: Jump to the last recursive call
Move to the middle of the array
Remove the last added element and explore new paths

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking involves undoing the last action to explore other valid options.

questionContent.body: In Combination Sum, which statement is true if an element can be used multiple times

questionOptions.body: Skip the current index after choosing
Use index+1 for the next call
Reuse the same index after choosing
Remove the element from the list

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Reusing the same index allows using the same element multiple times.

questionContent.body: Which approach is commonly used to solve Combination Sum problems

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking allows exploring all valid combinations efficiently by pruning invalid paths.

questionContent.body: What is the objective of the Combination Sum problem

questionOptions.body: Find all unique permutations of a list
Find all combinations of numbers adding up to a target

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Combination Sum problems aim to find all sets of elements that sum up to a specific target.

questionContent.body: In N-Queens, what do the values row - col and row + col represent when stored in HashSets

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: These expressions represent diagonals (main and anti-diagonals) in constant-time diagonal checks.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Placing invalid digits may break constraints and cause infinite recursion or wrong solution.

questionContent.body: In N-Queens, what is the advantage of using a boolean array for columns and diagonals

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Arrays track queen placements and allow constant-time conflict checks.

questionContent.body: What is the base case for the Sudoku recursive backtracking function

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The recursion ends when all 81 cells are filled with valid digits.

questionContent.body: Whats the backtracking step in Sudoku solving

questionOptions.body: Remove previously filled digit when conflict arises

solution.name: Solution 1

</svg>

questionOptions.body: To check if placing a queen causes conflicts

solution.name: Solution 1

questionContent.body: What is the time complexity of solving N-Queens using backtracking

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: For each row, we try n columns, leading to a factorial complexity in the worst case.

questionContent.body: Why is backtracking suitable for constraint satisfaction problems like Sudoku

questionOptions.body: It tries partial solutions and abandons invalid ones

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking prunes invalid solutions early and only explores valid paths.

questionContent.body: Which approach is used to solve Sudoku efficiently in programming

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Sudoku solvers typically use backtracking with constraint checks.

questionContent.body: What condition must be true in a valid Sudoku board

questionOptions.body: Every row must contain unique numbers 19
Every column must contain unique numbers 19
Each 3x3 box must contain unique numbers 19

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: All rows, columns, and 3x3 subgrids must have unique digits from 1 to 9.

questionContent.body: In a 9x9 Sudoku board, how many cells must be filled to complete the board

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A 9x9 Sudoku board has 81 cells that must be filled with valid digits.

questionContent.body: What constraints must be satisfied for placing a queen on the board

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Queens can attack in row, column, and both diagonals, so all must be checked.

questionContent.body: Which technique is most commonly used to solve the N-Queens problem

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: N-Queens is a classic backtracking problem where partial solutions are built and backtracked upon conflict.

questionContent.body: What is the objective of the N-Queens problem

questionOptions.body: Place N rooks on an NxN board
Place N queens such that no two attack each other
Find the shortest path in a maze

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: N-Queens problem requires placing N queens such that no two threaten each other on the board.

questionContent.body: What change is required in a permutation function to allow duplicates

questionOptions.body: Sort the input and skip duplicates

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Sort the input and skip duplicates at the same recursive depth to avoid duplicate permutations.

     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Power set = 2^n = 2^3 = 8.

questionContent.body: What is the backtracking step in permutation generation

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking is done by removing the element and marking it as unvisited.

questionContent.body: What does this function print for nums = [1, 2]

<svg width="1102" height="360"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" > 1 | 3osd permute(snt[] numi, boolean[] 3sisted, Lsit<Integer> current) {</text>
<text x="40" y="60" > 2 |     sf (current.isze() ?? numi.length) {</text>
<text x="40" y="80" > v |         Syitem.out.prsntln(current);</text>
<text x="40" y="100" > 4 |         return;</text>
<text x="40" y="120" > 5 |     }</text>
<text x="40" y="140" > 6 |     for (snt s ? 0; s < numi.length; s77) {</text>
<text x="40" y="160" > + |         sf (3sisted[s]) contsnue;</text>
<text x="40" y="180" > 8 |         3sisted[s] ? true;</text>
<text x="40" y="200" > 9 |         current.add(numi[s]);</text>
<text x="40" y="220" >10 |         permute(numi, 3sisted, current);</text>
<text x="40" y="240" >11 |         current.remo3e(current.isze() - 1);</text>
<text x="40" y="260" >12 |         3sisted[s] ? falie;</text>
<text x="40" y="280" >1v |     }</text>
<text x="40" y="300" >14 | }</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: All permutations of 2 elements are generated with backtracking.

questionContent.body: In permutation generation, what must be done after adding an element to the path

solution.name: Solution 1

solution.name: Solution 1

solution.name: Solution 1

questionContent.body: What is the time complexity of generating all permutations of n elements

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: There are n! permutations of n distinct elements.

questionContent.body: Which statement is true for the power set of {a, b}

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 2 elements -> 2^2 = 4 subsets -> {}, {a}, {b}, {a,b}.

questionContent.body: In permutation problems, why is a visited array often used

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A visited array tracks used elements to prevent reusing them in a single permutation.

questionContent.body: Which algorithm is commonly used for generating all permutations of a string or array

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Backtracking is used to build all permutations by exploring each possible decision.

questionContent.body: Which of the following problems is best solved using backtracking

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Generating subsets uses recursion and backtracking to explore all combinations.

questionContent.body: What is the number of permutations of n distinct elements

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: There are n! ways to arrange n distinct items.

questionContent.body: What is the total number of subsets (power set) of a set with n elements

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The power set of a set with n elements contains 2? subsets including the empty set.

questionContent.body: What will happen if you compute fibonacci(50) with naive recursion

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Naive recursion for large inputs is inefficient and can cause stack overflow.

questionContent.body: Why is memoization helpful in recursive Fibonacci

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Memoization caches previous results to avoid repeated work.

questionContent.body: What is the time complexity of naive recursive Fibonacci

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Each call makes two more calls, resulting in exponential time.

questionContent.body: What is the base case for a recursive Fibonacci function

questionContent.body: What is the time complexity of the recursive factorial function

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: One recursive call per number from n down to 1.

questionContent.body: Which statement is true for recursive factorial

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Recursive factorial follows n * factorial(n - 1).

What is the base case for a recursive factorial function

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The base case is typically factorial(0) = 1.

questionContent.body: What happens if the base case is missing in a recursive function

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Without a base case, recursion never stops, leading to stack overflow.

questionContent.body: What is the main drawback of recursion

questionOptions.body: Higher memory usage due to call stack

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Recursive calls are stored in the call stack and can cause stack overflow.

questionContent.body: Which of the following problems is best solved using recursion

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Recursive solutions are ideal for hierarchical data like trees.

questionContent.body: What is a base case in recursion

questionOptions.body: The point where the function begins

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The base case is the condition that stops further recursive calls.

questionContent.body: What is recursion in programming

questionOptions.body: A class that creates an object

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Recursion occurs when a function calls itself directly or indirectly.
